title: History of lower-case letterforms: book ideas?
content:
I’ve been reading about the history of modern European Latin letterforms, working from the assumption that the modern alphabet is actually a combination in practice of Roman capitals, Carolingian miniscule, and italic cursives, corresponding to our present-day uppercase, lowercase, and italics.

I’ve found good sources on the history of Roman letterforms (e.g., Gray’s _History of lettering_) and on the history of italics (e.g., Morison’s _Early italian writing books_ and Atkins’s _Masters of the italic letter_), but does anyone have recommendations for the precursors of the lower case Latin forms?

 [‹ Post-Colonial/Ethnography of type??](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905213418/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38969 "Go to previous forum topic") [London 2012 Olympic Logo ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905213418/http:/www.typophile.com/node/34223 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Maurice Meilleur

comments.content: There’s a chapter about origins of Latin minuscules in _The 26 Letters_. There’s probably also information scattered around in the European chapters of Mason’s _The History of the Art of Writing_, but given what a copy costs, skim around at a library first.

Oh yeah, Mason has it covered. Email [james.puckett@gmail.com](mailto:james.puckett@gmail.com) to get a 150 DPI tiff.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905213418im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/mason_minuscules_3715.jpg)
